title: PREVIEW: HengeMusic, Romsey Abbey
text:
0 comments 
A UNIQUE multi-media experience comes to Romsey Abbey on Friday October 30. 
Called HengeMusic it presents a year in the life of the extraordinary Neolithic henge at Knowlton in Dorset, with its ruined Norman church at its centre, and its yew-grove standing guard at the ceremonial entrance. 
It involves a remarkable musical union and interchange of a saxophone quartet and an organ, with spoken poetry and visual images and film by Rob Lambert. 
David Owen Norris, who lives in Andover, has written the music. His award-winning son - playwright, poet and novelist Barney Norris, 28, winner of the Critics’ Circle and Off West End Most Promising Playwright Awards, 2014, will be reciting his poems with musical accompaniment. 
David told the Daily Echo:"The idea is that the organ represents the landscape and the forces of nature, while the saxophones represent humanity, acting out successive human interventions across the centuries, and Barney's poems slot in there." 
The music blends melodic counterpoint with jazz chords and rhythms to create a unique language of its own, and the line-up of world-class performers - John Harle, Rob Buckland, Paul Stevens, Andy Findon (saxophones) and Sarah Baldock ( organ) should guarantee an electrifying experience. Promoted stories 
It is David Owen Norris’s second new piece this autumn. The first, Turning Points, a cantata for chorus, children’s choir, vocal soloists, orchestra, brass band, electric guitars, piano duet and organ, commissioned by the Agincourt Commemoration Committee, was experienced live by well over a thousand people in its first couple of weeks. 
One French reviewer wrote: ‘I can only sketch a skeleton of this astounding piece. It deserves a whole book to itself.’ 
Sir Geoffrey Hill, Oxford Professor of Poetry, wrote: ‘Your music is powerfully and beautifully your own.’ 
Barney Norris’s new play Eventide is currently on tour. ‘A play that captures all the still, sad, music of humanity.’ Michael Billington in The Guardian. 
‘A writer-chronicler to be cherished.’ Evening Standard

*Barney Norris will bring his new play 'Eventide' to Salisbury Playhouse next month ( November 3-7) which both celebrates and mourns changing rural communities in Hampshire. 
It comes on a short UK tour direct from glowing critical acclaim in London and is a co-production between Barney's theatre company Up In Arms and Arcola Theatre.
